main.name: Kevin Yao
main.occupation: Goldwater Scholar, Davidson Fellow, and TAMU Brown Scholar pursuing Computer Engineering
main.description: I am dedicated to researching and developing machine learning and software solutions to global healthcare issues
main.bio: I am programmer, researcher, physicist, and aspiring physician. The type to spend his summer days taking classes and evenings self-learning quantum mechanics and deep learning. To pursue medical school while majoring in computer engineering. To work in three research labs involving investigating next-generation two-dimensional nanomaterials, developing a mobile application to examine strokes, and developing my own deep learning models for prediction of cancer prognosis. And to powerlift, dance, and play guitar. In it all, I have found that being able to LEARN is the most exciting aspect of life. My next steps in my career is to work in a tech company, gain experience in tech leadership, and earn a M.D., allowing me to determine and innnovate computational solutions to imminent healthcare issues.
main.contactmessage: Please contact me using the below form, or by email or phone if you have any questions.

resume.skillmessage: Here is a list of a couple of my skills

education.description: Brown Scholar, pursued computer science and electrical engineering courses with a focus on machine learning and software development

education.school: Texas Academy of Math and Science
education.description: Private boarding school, where I attended computer sciences with other undergraduate students at the University of North Texas

work.title: Software Development Engineer Intern
work.description: I designed and defended a new architecture to execute SQL queries in DynanmoDB. I also deployed AWS redshift cluster, scheduled lambda, and other AWS resources with Golang/Java. Lastly, I fronted SQL query support for Docker Containers, which decreased on-call workload by ~6 hrs/month

work.title: Senior Undergraduate Researcher
work.description: I devised, validated, and reported a multiple-gene signature to predict prognosis of breast cancer. I also developed convolutional neural networks for analysis of histopathology images using Pytorch. Lastly, I have utilized statistical and machine learning methods in R such as Random Forest.

work.title: Software Engineer, Researcher
work.description: I produced a mobile application interface using Unity/Swift to optimize patient-doctor interaction, and developed and connected a Django-based backend to frontend for stroke prediction on the cloud. I also developed machine learning models and processing to determine patient risk for stroke on the NIHSS scale

work.title: Senior Researcher, Lab Manager
work.description: I discovered and led a project on degradation of MoS2 in air and developed novel degradation prevention methods. I also conceived of and orchestrated the characterization the stability of MoS2 bilayers in air. Lastly, I managed lab members, assisted and mentored new students, and led weekly meetings.

work.title: Co-founder, Co-president, and Product Manager
work.description: I organized and led a 20-person executive team to outreach, market, and develop website. I conceived of new programs for underprivileged students to be introduced to research. I also reached out to professors and students through presentations.

testimonials.text: His research is on the same level as a 2nd or 3rd year graduate student, and would qualify him for a pH.D. in our department
testimonials.user: Dr. Jose Perez, research PI at physics lab in UNT

testimonials.text: I have mentored and supervised 58 MS/PhD/MD-PhD students and 45 senior undergraduates at UC Berkeley, UCSF, Harvard University, and Rice University, many of them are full or chair professors in academia or senior scientists in industry. Kevin is among the top few undergraduates I have worked with.
testimonials.user: Dr. Stephen Wong, research PI at Houston Methodist
